docs.lead_paragraph: YEAR by year, the evidence has mounted. People who have heart disease are likely to be depressed, people with depression seem more likely to develop heart disease, and depression combined with heart disease is a double dose of adversity -- patients have a miserable life and tend to die sooner. So medical researchers, in coming to believe that there is an intimate connection between depression and heart disease, are trying to decide which is cause and which is effect, and how the apparent link between the two might be broken.

headline.main: Which Comes First: Depression or Heart Disease?

docs.abstract: Evidence of a correlation between heart disease and depression prompts research on which is the cause and which the effect and on how the apparent link between the two might be broken; one theory on how depression might cause heart disease focuses on well-documented biochemical changes that occur in depressed people, like the secretion of stress hormones, while another suggests that depressed people do not take care of their health and may neglect to take medications like those that control high blood pressure, leaving themselves vulnerable to heart disease; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN work that sounds a little like scientific blasphemy, medical researchers have begun paying increasing attention to some beneficial effects of nicotine that were first noticed in cigarette smokers. After years of quiet discussion among scientists, hints that cigarettes can protect against some diseases or improve the outcome of others have led to growing interest in finding out why. This has focused attention on nicotine, tobacco's most active ingredient, as a potential treatment for several major health problems, including Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases.
docs.abstract: Medical researchers probe beneficial effects of nicotine that were first noted in cigarette smokers, including properties that might be useful in treating Parkinson's and Alzheimer's diseases; research has risen with recent development of nicotine in nontobacco forms and with better understanding of how the chemical works in the body, particularly in the brain; smokers have been found to have half the risk of developing Parkinson's disease as those who have never smoked, and nicotine appears to interfere with the formation of beta amyloid plaque deposits in Alzheimer's patients; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE actress Kathleen Turner is known for many roles, but none in which she is a victim. She always appears self-assured. Her major movies include ''Body Heat'' with William Hurt, ''The War of the Roses'' with Danny DeVito, ''Peggy Sue'' and ''Serial Mom.'' On stage she appeared on Broadway in Tennessee Williams's ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.''
docs.abstract: Interview with actress Kathleen Turner focuses on involvement in Suffolk County, NY, center for battered women called the Retreat; photo (L)
